title: HTMLLanguage CodeReference

metadata.description: Learn about HTMLLanguage CodeReference with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
ISO Language Codes
You should always include the
lang
attribute inside the
<html>
tag, to declare the language of the 
Web page. This is meant to assist search engines and browsers:
<html lang="en">
...
</html>
In XHTML, the language is declared inside the
<html>
tag as follows:
<html xmlns="" lang="en" xml:lang="en">
...
</html>
ISO 639-1 Language Codes
ISO 639-1 defines abbreviations for languages:
See also:
Reference for Country Codes
.

practice_exercises.title: Practice Exercise
practice_exercises.description: Create an example that applies the concepts from this tutorial.

related_topics.title: C Common Pitfalls and How to Avoid Them

quiz.question: What is This?
options:
declared inside the
<html>
tag as follows:
<html xmlns="" lang="en" xml:lang="en">

meant to assist search engines and browsers:
<html lang="en">
quiz.explanation:
The correct definition of This is 'meant to assist search engines and browsers:
<html lang="en">'.

quiz.question: What is the language?
options:
declared inside the
<html>
tag as follows:
<html xmlns="" lang="en" xml:lang="en">

meant to assist search engines and browsers:
<html lang="en">
quiz.explanation:
The correct definition of the language is 'declared inside the
<html>
tag as follows:
<html xmlns="" lang="en" xml:lang="en">'.

summary: This tutorial covers HTMLLanguage CodeReference concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use HTMLLanguage CodeReference effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of HTMLLanguage CodeReference and how to apply it in your projects.
